speaker: Patient
text: So, I woke up with these big purple spots on my arm again, and I swear I haven’t bumped into anything, but the visiting nurse looked worried and sent that report. Now I feel like I messed something up.

speaker: Patient
text: She kept asking if I doubled the aspirin or skipped the folic acid, and I got flustered, because, well, the pill box was kind of mixed up after my granddaughter visited last weekend, and all.

speaker: Patient
text: Honestly, the methotrexate day is Tuesdays, right, but with the holiday I took it Wednesday evening instead, and now I’m panicking that the timing with the new prednisone schedule is wrong and that’s why the bruises exploded all over me in just one weird night.

speaker: Clinician
text: It’s okay, really, I’m glad you flagged it, because bruising can show up even when you do everything right. The side-effect alert just popped on my screen too, so let’s walk through the timing together.

speaker: Clinician
text: First, aspirin stays at 81 milligrams each breakfast, no doubling. Methotrexate is ten milligrams once weekly, preferably Tuesday morning with water, and folic acid one milligram every single day still.

speaker: Patient
text: Alright, but I, um, sometimes wake up late and the Tuesday pill ends up closer to noon than breakfast. Does that wreck the spacing? And if my hand hurts that morning, could I still take an extra Tylenol for pain.

speaker: Clinician
text: Your next adalimumab injection lands this Friday; take it before lunch, not the same day as methotrexate. That spacing cuts the bruise risk a bit.

speaker: Clinician
text: Prednisone starts at ten milligrams tomorrow, then drop by one milligram every five days—slow and steady to give your skin.

speaker: Clinician
text: I’ve messaged the nurse to update the pill organizer colors: blue for steroids, yellow for methotrexate, easy visual cue too.

speaker: Clinician
text: If a bruise gets larger than a quarter or feels warm, snap a photo and call me the same day.

speaker: Clinician
text: Meanwhile, keep the blood pressure log, because prednisone can nudge numbers up; amlodipine stays five milligrams nightly just like before.

speaker: Patient
text: And, uh, the taper chart—could you print it big? My reading glasses are useless at night, and I’d rather tape the schedule right on the fridge for quick double checks.

speaker: Patient
text: I also found an old bottle of 5-milligram prednisone from last winter. Should I toss it, or can we use those for the smaller steps instead of cutting the big tablets? They crumble so easily.

speaker: Patient
text: One more thing—I’m embarrassed to ask, but if the bruises keep showing, my bridge group will notice. Is it okay to dab a little cover-up makeup, or will that irritate the skin too much maybe.
